awd_titl_txt: EFRI NewLAW: Voltage-tuned, topologically-protected magnon states for low loss microwave devices and circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the development of voltage-controlled magnetic materials for low loss microwave devices and circuits, including isolators and circulators which are key components that allow one way signal propagation. A key innovation of this program is the use of an organic-based magnetic material to construct the microwave circuits, much in the same way that organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) have allowed new display technologies. This approach leverages existing infrastructure developed for commercial microwave magnetic devices. Given the critical role those devices play in wireless communication and information technology, the breadth and depth of the impact of this work will be significant. Additionally, this research program will form the foundation for broader efforts at increasing public engagement in science via local outreach activities that are designed to enhance diversity programs in STEM across the four participating university campuses (Colorado State University, University of Iowa, Ohio State University, and Yale University). 

This project focuses on the development of novel approaches to achieving/enhancing non-reciprocity in microwave devices. Specifically, we have defined two parallel and synergistic Tracks that exploit the existing infrastructure surrounding magnetic-based microwave devices as a springboard for the development of novel device architectures based on high-fidelity self-biased magnonic crystals (Track 1) and voltage-control via the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction (Track 2). In both of these architectures, topologically protected propagating states will be exploited to dramatically enhance non-reciprocity in microwave devices such as circulators, isolators, and non-reciprocal filters. These projects are critically enabled by a recent materials breakthrough in which thin films of a room temperature organic-based magnet have been shown to exhibit magnetic ordering temperatures of over 600 K, quality factors in excess of 8,000 for magnetic resonance, conformal and low temperature deposition, and materials stability under ambient conditions. These projects are individually impactful and collectively synergistic, providing multiple paths to technological advances that will transform the phase space for the design of non-reciprocal microwave devices.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
This research program focused on the development of novel approaches to achieving/enhancing non-reciprocity in microwave devices. Specifically, we explored the potential for patterned magnetic materials to serve as one-way valves for microwave energy, allowing it to propagate forward but not backward through the device. This work was critically enabled by a recent materials breakthrough in which thin films of a room temperature organic-based magnet have been shown to exhibit magnetic ordering temperatures of over 600 K, quality factors in excess of 8,000 for magnetic resonance, conformal and low temperature deposition, and materials stability under ambient conditions. During this program we exploited these superb magnetic properties to demonstrate the ability to fabricate magnetic microstructures using standard techniques developed by the microelectronics industry. This successful demonstration laid the foundation for quantiative device modeling predicting how microwave devices based on this material would behave, and laying a theoretical foundation for understanding how that behavior could be further improved with patterning.

The direct scientific and technical impact of this research program formed the foundation for broader efforts at increasing public engagement in science and broadening access to and participation in the STEM pipeline. In addition to biweekly videoconferencing between team members to coordinate ongoing research activities, our team held workshops every 6 – 12 months, as appropriate, where both PIs and students will meet for in-person discussions and detailed reporting of ongoing activities. In addition to the scientific program, these workshops allowed for the students supported by this program to network internally, experiencing the differing research environments of the four participating institutions, and participating in local outreach activities. For example, Johnston-Halperin is a founding member of Ohio State’s MS to PhD Bridge Program, Flatté works closely with Iowa’s STEM Innovator program (a collaboration between the College of Education and the US Patent Office focused on mentoring K-12 students), Buchanan mentors CSU’s Women in Physics (WiP) undergraduate student group, and Tang coordinates the outreach resources offered by Yale Pathways to Science, which serves a diverse urban student body in New Haven area with a high proportion of economically disadvantaged families.


Last Modified: 01/04/2024
Modified by: Ezekiel Johnston-Halperin
